reviews.review:
The difference between episode one and Half Life 2 is that there's more interesting level design, presenting for fun combat at times.

Some notable examples include the elevator in the dark, which gives tension and inspires fear within the player, as well as the hospital, which is enclosed but still has enough room for fun room-to-room combat.

My only complaint would be with the final boss fight, which is just not fun due to how striders in Half Life work.

The soundtrack also improves with Episode 1, with more melodic tracks and less cold ambience, making it feel like a legitimate warzone. Still not perfect, but at least a significantly more enjoyable experience.
Wasn't as good as the base game, however it was still very entertaining. Would highly reccomend.
Amazing you can beat the game with 1 bullet
One of the weak ones in the series, but still solid.
if you have half life 2, you need the episodes
Cada entrega es una mejora en todos los aspectos del juego, de lo mejor de este siglo.

After playing Half Life 2, I was pretty hyped to play this extencion. From what I was told, I was aware that it's not some sort of typical DLC or boring prequel that is supposed to milk the game to its limits. I knew what I will be experiencing and the real question was - will it be something so good that it will seem like a genuine continuation of what happened after destroying Citadel's reactor and the answer to this question is actually not as obvious as everyone remembers it to be. 
 We start the game at the same place it was cut back in the plot of original Half Life 2. The reactor is about to blow up, while G Man is trying to, once again, incarcerate Gordon Freeman and put him out of time and space in order to control them. This time, though, group of friendly Vortigaunts manage to stop G Man, so that we can escape the Citadel with Alyx. The plot of Episode 1 is very straightforward, our only task is to escape CIty 17 before the reactor irrevocably collapses, but once again choosing a way of getting through locations is going to determine how we will eventually perceive the whole story. What I personally don't like about Episode's 1 narration, is how similar it is to final moments of Half Life 2. Of course Valve tried to refresh the Citadel and destroyed City 17, but in some parts of the plot it kinda feels like running HL2 backwards. On the other hand, Episode 1 brought back something that hadn't been present in franchise since the original Half Life. I'm talking about the more horror approach which Episode 1 recaptures very well and in my honest opinion it's a very enjoyable addition, given that HL2 didn't have so many of similar moments. To conclude, plot of this extencion is pretty basic, lacks of shocking momentum of Half Life 2, but definitely adds old yet refreshing things to the table.
 There's really nothing new added in terms of graphics in this game - it's the same as in the standard version of Half Life 2 and that's actually not bad. World design and entourage are still feel very realistic, maybe enriched a little bit with more murky vibe and I loved that. There are so many soul crashing yet eye pleasing
views that my soul feels fed. Absolute classic of a game design.
 Once again you will have a pleasure to use Gravity gun and all of the weapons everyone loves. If you fell in love with Half Life 2 mechanics, I can promise you that you won't be disappointed.
 Altough it's just a small extencion, Episode 1 is capable of bringing the same joy as playing HL2 and that's why it was even created in the first place. It can get stale and predictable sometimes, but overall it's a very decent continuation and that's why it's a solid ùü¥/ùü≠ùü¨
some say its not worth playing but i find it fun

I quite liked this game but this was where the game series really started to go down a lot for me. As a girl, I didn't enjoy being introducted to a Alyx originally in 2 as "cool" and "independent" to then have her made a form of "weak sidekick" to Freeman. If this were the case, she should never have been introduced as independent, but as the character she was intended to be. Which is fine, just felt brutal to observe, as she was so cool, was a harsh jump in character design. I get they were trying to make her someone the player felt cool to be dating, but bringing out the VR Alyx was fixing the issue. Going into her back story, which was what I expected to at least be splattered into the Original HL2 game, as she was a new introduced character. All round this was a good game though.
Too short but still very good. In terms of atmosphere I guess I enjoyed this episode more than episode two.
A great continuation of the Half-Life franchise, but out of 2, 2.1, and 2.2, 2.1 is the worst one of the 3...
Its a great followup to HL 2, just a little short. Its a little expensive, but it's still a good game. If you really don't have 8 bucks to spare, just wait until it goes on sale.

Half Life 2 was great, episode 1 is great aswell, but does not bring new stuff to the table except story advancement.
It's just more Half Life gameplay that you kind of already experienced in Hl2, which may or may not bother you if you like Hl2 gameplay or just want to know how the story progresses, if it's the latter just look up a playthrough.
But it's probably fine if you don't play HL2 and Ep.1 back to back.

It's a good game but it can be beaten in 3 hours. I'm glad for the Orange Box deal and the Steam sales, I can't imagine how people must have felt back in 2006 when they waited an entire year and bought this full price and beat it in just one sitting. I'd have been pretty mad. 

Price and length aside, the puzzles are a bit more creative than the ones you see in HL2 but some parts get extremely annoying, like being in the pitch black underground full of antlions and zombies with low flashlight battery.
Very Good Game, Half life 2 is worth the price to buy had a lot of fun would recommend a lot.
